questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient is told about the benefits and complications of hysterectomy and she agrees to the procedure. What kind of consent is this? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Informed consent

 

Informed consent is obtained when a patient is provided with comprehensive information about a medical procedure, including its benefits, risks, and possible complications, and then agrees to undergo the procedure. This ensures that the patient's decision is based on an understanding of all relevant information.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Implied consent: Implied consent is assumed when a patient visits a healthcare provider for a basic examination. It does not apply to invasive procedures like surgery.

 

Option C. Opt out: Opt-out consent is used when consent is presumed unless the individual actively declines. This is not applicable in the context of medical procedures requiring explicit consent.

 

Option D. Passive consent: Passive consent typically refers to situations where consent is inferred from a lack of objection. This is not applicable in medical contexts where explicit, informed consent is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Consent can be classified in two ways:

 

1. Based on how the consent is given

 

 

2. Based on how much information provided:

questions.text: In comparison to Bochdalek hernias, Morgagni hernias are: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Less common

 

Morgagni hernias are congenital diaphragmatic hernias that occur anteriorly through the foramen of Morgagni (space of Larrey), which is located between the sternal and costal attachments of the diaphragm. These hernias are significantly less common than Bochdalek hernias, accounting for only about 2-3% of all congenital diaphragmatic hernias. Unlike Bochdalek hernias, Morgagni hernias are typically smaller in size, tend to be right-sided, and are anterior rather than posterior in location.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior in location - This is incorrect as Morgagni hernias are anterior diaphragmatic hernias. It's actually Bochdalek hernias that occur posterolaterally through the posterolateral defect in the diaphragm.

 

Option C. Larger in size - This is incorrect as Morgagni hernias are typically smaller than Bochdalek hernias. Bochdalek hernias are often large enough to allow significant herniation of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity.

 

Option D. More frequently left-sided - This is incorrect as Morgagni hernias are more commonly right-sided (90% of cases) or bilateral, whereas Bochdalek hernias are more frequently left-sided (approximately 80-85% of cases).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Morgagni hernias are less common anterior diaphragmatic hernias that are typically right-sided, in contrast to the more common, left-sided, posterior Bochdalek hernias.

questions.text: A patient was admitted with complaints of tachycardia, arrhythmias. On examination, multiple scratch marks were present over the body. Probable drug of abuse in above patient is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine

 

Cocaine is a powerful sympathomimetic drug that stimulates the central nervous system, leading to symptoms such as tachycardia (rapid heart rate) and arrhythmias (irregular heartbeats). One of the distinctive signs of cocaine abuse is the presence of multiple scratch marks on the body. This occurs due to tactile hallucinations, commonly referred to as "cocaine bugs" or "formication/ Magnan Symptoms" where the user feels as though insects are crawling on or under their skin, causing them to scratch incessantly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morphine: Morphine is a central nervous system depressant, not a stimulant. It typically causes bradycardia (slow heart rate) rather than tachycardia or arrhythmias. It also does not produce tactile hallucinations or scratch marks.

 

Option C. Datura: Although Datura can cause tachycardia and arrhythmias due to its anticholinergic properties, it is not commonly known as a drug of abuse. Moreover, Datura does not typically cause the tactile hallucinations that result in scratch marks.

 

Option D. Cannabis: Cannabis has minimal physiological effects compared to cocaine. It is unlikely to cause significant tachycardia or arrhythmias. Cannabis also does not cause tactile hallucinations or the resultant scratch marks seen with cocaine use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine abuse can be identified by symptoms of tachycardia, arrhythmias, and the presence of scratch marks due to tactile hallucinations (cocaine bugs).

 

“Cocaine is the drug of abuse”

questions.text: Which of the following nerves does not lie in close contact with the humerus? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Musculocutaneous Nerve

 

The musculocutaneous nerve does not lie in close contact with the humerus along its course. This nerve originates from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus (C5-C7) and travels through the anterior compartment of the arm. Importantly, it pierces the coracobrachialis muscle and then passes between the biceps and brachialis muscles, staying within the soft tissue compartments without establishing a close relationship with the humeral bone.

The musculocutaneous nerve supplies the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm (coracobrachialis, biceps brachii, and brachialis) and continues as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm for sensory distribution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Axillary Nerve - This nerve does lie in close contact with the humerus, specifically at the surgical neck. It courses around the neck of the humerus in the quadrangular space, making it vulnerable to injury in proximal humeral fractures and anterior shoulder dislocations.

 

Option B. Radial Nerve - This nerve has an intimate relationship with the humerus as it travels in the spiral groove (radial groove) on the posterior aspect of the humerus. This close relationship makes it the most commonly injured nerve in humeral shaft fractures, especially in the middle and lower third.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve - The ulnar nerve comes into close contact w`ith the humerus at the medial epicondyle. At the elbow, it passes behind the medial epicondyle in the cubital tunnel, making it vulnerable to injury at this site (cubital tunnel syndrome).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nerves that lie in close contact with bones are more susceptible to injury during fractures, and the musculocutaneous nerve is relatively protected as it travels through soft tissue compartments without establishing close contact with the humerus, unlike the axillary, radial, and ulnar nerves.

questions.text: A person was stabbed in the thigh by a knife, with a wound measuring 1×3×5 cm. What kind of wound is this? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Penetration

 

Explanation:

 

A wound is classified based on depth, entry and exit points, and the type of weapon used.

 

In this stab wound:

 

  • Depth (5 cm) > length (3 cm) > width (1 cm)
  • Penetrates deep into tissue
  • No exit wound mentioned 
  • Penetrating: Extends deep into cavity/tissue without exit
  • Perforating: Has both entry and exit wounds
  • Puncture: Only involves superficial tissues 

 

Types of stab wounds based on depth:

 

This case shows penetrating wound as it's deep (5 cm) but doesn't exit the body

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Perforating Wound: Incorrect

 

  • Involves both entry and exit wounds.
  • Example: A stab wound passing through the body and weapon coming out from other side.
  • Here, no exit wound is mentioned, ruling out this option.

 

Option C. Incision: Incorrect

 

  • Length is greater than depth (e.g., surgical cuts, knife slashes).
  • Here, depth (5 cm) is greater than length (1 cm), ruling out an incision.

 

Option D. Puncture Wound: Incorrect

 

  • Shallow depth, usually involving only the superficial layers.
  • Seen in  nail, or small pointed object injuries.
  • Here, the depth is significantly deep (5 cm), making it penetrating, not puncture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A penetrating wound is defined as a deep wound where depth > length, caused by sharp-pointed objects (e.g., knife, dagger, spear). A perforating wound would require both an entry and exit wound, which is not present here​

choices.text: Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount
Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions
It is not a sexually transmitted infection

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

 

Trichomonas vaginalis has a jerky or twitching type of motility on the wet saline mount.

 

Lab Diagnosis for Trichomonas:

 

  1. Direct Microscopy: Wet (saline) mount of fresh samples jerky motile trophozoites and pus cells. Cystic stage not seen.
  2. Culture: Gold standard method for diagnosis.
  3. Serology: Antigen Detection in Vaginal Secretion:
    • More sensitive than microscopy
    • Indicates recent infection
    • ELISA uses monoclonal antibodies.
    • Antibody Detection by ELISA - whole cell antigen preparation
  4. Molecular Methods: Highly sensitive targeting T. vaginalis specific genes - beta-tubulin gene.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It cannot be cultured: Incorrect, as Trichomonas vaginalis can indeed be cultured and this is considered the gold standard for its diagnosis.

 

Option C. Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions: Incorrect, Trichomonas vaginalis does not produce cysts; it exists only in trophozoite form.

 

Option D. It is not a sexually transmitted infection: Incorrect, as it is a well-known sexually transmitted infection.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following are initial management options of CSF rhinorrhea except: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Steroids followed by FESS

 

Steroids followed by FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery): This option is incorrect because steroids and FESS are primarily used for treating chronic rhinosinusitis and nasal polyposis. FESS is not an initial management option for CSF rhinorrhea; it is not related to repairing the skull base defect causing the CSF leak.

 

CSF rhinorrhea is the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid through the nose, often due to a defect in the skull base. Initial management focuses on conservative measures to allow spontaneous healing and to prevent complications such as meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bed rest: Advising the patient to take bed rest and avoid activities that increase intracranial pressure is a standard initial approach. This helps reduce the flow of CSF and may allow the defect to heal on its own.

 

Option C. HRCT (High-Resolution CT): HRCT is useful for diagnosing the exact site and cause of the CSF leak. It helps in planning further treatment if conservative measures fail.

 

Option D. Antibiotics and Acetazolamide: Antibiotics are given to prevent infections such as meningitis. Acetazolamide, a diuretic, reduces CSF production and intracranial pressure, which can help reduce the leak.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of CSF rhinorrhea includes conservative measures such as bed rest, use of acetazolamide, and antibiotics to prevent infection. Diagnostic imaging like HRCT can help identify the defect. Steroids followed by FESS is not appropriate for the initial management of CSF rhinorrhea as it is unrelated to addressing the CSF leak.

questions.text: A farmer is on a maize-based diet and develops skin rashes on the face, neck, and hand. Which of the following should be given? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

The farmer’s symptoms of skin rashes in sun-exposed areas like the face, neck, and hands are characteristic of pellagra, a condition caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. Maize-based diets are deficient in tryptophan, which is necessary for niacin synthesis in the body. Pellagra is characterized by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, with the dermatitis presenting as symmetrical, pigmented, and scaly skin rashes. Providing niacin supplementation is the appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency causes beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, not pellagra. The symptoms of thiamine deficiency are primarily neurological and cardiovascular, not dermatological.

 

Option C. Retinol: Retinol (vitamin A) deficiency leads to visual problems, including night blindness and xerophthalmia, and does not cause skin rashes typical of pellagra.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to anemia and neurological symptoms, including neuropathy and cognitive disturbances. It does not cause skin rashes or dermatitis associated with niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin deficiency in individuals consuming a maize-based diet can lead to pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Niacin supplementation is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Identify the clinical sign shown in the image below:(NEET  PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Popeye sign

 

The above image depicts the popeye sign, which is caused by a rupture of the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii.

 

Popeye sign:

 

  • Description: This refers to the prominent bulge of the biceps muscle in the arm.
  • Cause: The sign is named after the cartoon character "Popeye the Sailor Man" who had bulging forearm muscles. It's observed in cases where there's a rupture of the long head of the biceps tendon. When the tendon ruptures, the muscle can sometimes ball up, creating a bulge in the mid-arm.
  • Clinical Relevance: Often accompanied by pain and weakness, it usually requires clinical evaluation to determine the need for surgical intervention.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hill-Sachs sign (or lesion):

 

  • Description: It is a compression fracture of the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head.
  • Cause: This lesion occurs when the humeral head impacts against the anterior glenoid rim during an anterior shoulder dislocation.
  • Clinical Relevance: The presence of a Hill-Sachs lesion can predispose an individual to recurrent shoulder dislocations. Its size and location may dictate treatment strategy in recurrent shoulder instability.

 

 

Option C. Griesinger sign:

 

  • Description: It refers to the presence of a postauricular sulcus or groove behind the ear.
  • Cause: This sign is seen in cases of acute mastoiditis, a complication of acute otitis media. The groove results from the edema and venous congestion in the sigmoid sinus secondary to the adjacent inflammation.
  • Clinical Relevance: Acute mastoiditis is a serious condition that requires prompt treatment, often including surgical intervention. The presence of Griesinger's sign helps in clinical diagnosis.

 

Option D. Rising sun sign:

 

  • Description: This is a radiological sign observed on imaging of the head.
  • Cause: It's seen in cases of tuberous sclerosis, a genetic disorder. On imaging, it refers to the appearance of subependymal nodules in the lateral ventricles that project into the ventricle. The nodules resemble the sun rising over the horizon.
  • Clinical Relevance: Tuberous sclerosis is characterized by the growth of benign tumors in many parts of the body. The presence of the "Rising sun" sign can help confirm the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Popeye sign is a clinical indication of the rupture of the long head of the biceps tendon, leading to a characteristic bulging of the biceps muscle, which requires thorough clinical assessment and possibly surgical repair.

questions.text: Out of the options given below the most common habit-forming drug is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Heroin

 

Heroin is an opioid and is the most commonly abused opioid. Heroin has the highest dependence potential among all drugs listed. It is highly addictive, and users can develop a strong physical dependence, leading to withdrawal symptoms if the drug is not taken.

 

Most commonly abused drugs: This can vary from one country to another. Generally, alcohol, tobacco, cannabis, opioids are most commonly abused drugs:

 

  • Alcohol is the most common Used/Abused Substance in the World
  • Tobacco is the most common Used/Abused Substance in India
  • Cannabis is the most common “illegally” used drug in India as well as world, though its dependence potential is relatively lower.
  • Heroin is the most commonly abused opioid, and is the drug with highest dependence potential amongst all the drugs.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Ketamine: Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic with some potential for abuse, but it is not as commonly abused or as habit-forming.

 

Option C. LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide) is a hallucinogen. It can be abused, but it does not have the same level of physical dependence potential.

 

Option D. Phencyclidine (PCP): PCP is a dissociative drug with some potential for abuse, but it is not as commonly abused or as habit-forming drug.

 

Educational Objective

 

Common habit-forming drugs:

 

  • Cannabis
  • Opioids
  • Amphetamine and prescription stimulants
  • Ecstasy
  • Cocaine

 

Heroin is the most common drug which is habit forming or in other words can cause physical dependence in which a patient gets withdrawal if he does not take the drug.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of the nervous system, which of the following nerves can be tested by touching the highlighted structure? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. IX

 

The structure marked is uvula. The sensory supply to the uvula is by the glossopharyngeal nerve and it is tested in this case.

 

Motor supply to the Uvula is by vagus nerve and sensory supply by Glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Since touch is sensory activity hence the answer is sensory nerve CN IX in this case.

 

If the movement is stressed in question then motor nerve (CN X) will be the answer

 

Cranial Nerve IX (Glossopharyngeal Nerve) innervates -

 

Sensory: Supplies sensation to the posterior one-third of the tongue, oropharynx, and part of the ear canal. It also has a role in taste for the posterior third of the tongue.

 

Motor: Supplies the stylopharyngeus muscle.

 

Parasympathetic: Involved in salivation via the parotid gland.

 

Clinical Examination: Sensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue can be tested using a cotton swab. The gag reflex can also be used to test the glossopharyngeal nerve where the gag reflex is triggered by touching the back of the throat or as the nerve innervates the uvula, touching it could also elicit a response, verifying the integrity of the nerve.

 

Pharyngeal plexus:

 

The nerve supply to the pharynx is primarily provided by the pharyngeal plexus. The pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and the vagus nerve combine to form it. It also receives input from the superior cervical ganglion. The motor supply is provided by the vagus nerve, and the sensory supply is provided by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cranial Nerve X (Vagus Nerve): It gives innervations

 

  • Sensory: Provides sensation to parts of the ear canal and the pharynx. It also has visceral sensory functions for the heart, lungs, and abdominal organs.
  • Motor: Supplies muscles of the larynx, pharynx, and soft palate. It's also responsible for the "cough reflex."
  • Parasympathetic: Supplies the heart, lungs, and digestive tract up to the splenic flexure of the colon.
    • Clinical Examination: The gag reflex is a common method to test the vagus nerve (motor component) since it's responsible for the upward movement of the palate or Examining the uvula when saying "ahh" to see if it deviates (it should stay midline).

 

Option C. Cranial Nerve XI (Accessory Nerve): Supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

  • Clinical Examination: Patients are asked to turn their head against resistance to test the sternocleidomastoid or Patients are asked to shrug their shoulders against resistance to test the trapezius.

 

Option D. Cranial Nerve XII (Hypoglossal Nerve): Supplies the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue.

 

  • Clinical Examination: The patient is asked to protrude their tongue. If the nerve is damaged, the tongue will deviate to the side of the lesion.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male has the following buccal mucosa finding. After three days, he presents to your OPD with a rash. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

Based on the given information, the most likely diagnosis for the 3-year-old male with buccal mucosa findings followed by a rash after three days is Measles.

 

  • Measles is a viral illness that commonly affects children. It typically starts with flu-like symptoms such as fever, cough, runny nose, and red, watery eyes.
  • One of the hallmark signs of measles is the presence of Koplik spots, which are small, white, grain-like lesions that appear on the buccal mucosa.
  • A rash usually follows the appearance of Koplik spots. This rash typically starts on the face and neck and then spreads to the rest of the body.
  • If you suspect that a child has measles, it is essential to isolate them and refer them to a healthcare facility for further evaluation and treatment.
  • Lymphadenopathy may also be present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leukoplakia: Leukoplakia is a benign condition characterized by white patches on the mucous membranes. It is not associated with fever and rash.

 

Option C. Scarlet fever: Scarlet fever is caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci and presents with a URI (upper respiratory infection) and a sandpaper-like rash. It does not have Koplik spots.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash, and conjunctivitis but lacks Koplik spots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles is characterized by the presence of Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa followed by a widespread rash, starting from the face and neck.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with dark urine, which further blackens on exposure to air. What’s the enzyme defect in this case?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Di Hydroxy Phenyl Acetate Dioxygenase

 

This is a case of alkaptonuria which is an inborn error in catabolism of tyrosine and phenylalanine. Enzyme deficient is Homogentisate Dioxygenase or Di-Hydroxy Phenyl Acetate Dioxygenase. The IUPAC name of homogentisate is 2,5-Dihydroxy Phenyl Acetate. The older name of this enzyme was Homogentisate oxidase. (not Homogentisate Dehydrogenase).

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase:

  • Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase is an enzyme involved in the breakdown of tyrosine, an amino acid. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Tyrosinemia Type I. However, Tyrosinemia Type I does not cause darkening of urine upon exposure to air.

 

Option C. Homogentisate Dehydrogenase

  • Homogentisate oxidase, (not Homogentisate Dehydrogenase) is the enzyme responsible for the metabolism of homogentisic acid. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Alkaptonuria. In Alkaptonuria, homogentisic acid accumulates and causes the urine to turn black upon exposure to air. This is due to the oxidation of homogentisic acid.
     

 

Option D. Phenylalanine hydroxylase:

  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of phenylalanine, another amino acid. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Phenylketonuria (PKU). PKU does not directly lead to darkening of urine upon exposure to air.

 

Educational objective:

 

In alkaptonuria patients, fresh urine is normal in color, but on standing it turns black due to oxidation of excess homogentisic acid. Homogentisic acid is an intermediate in the catabolism of Tyrosine. For complete list of phenyalanine and tyrosine catabolism defects, refer to topic aromatic amino acids.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 286

choices.text: Resection of the diseased segment and end-to-end anastomosis
Cleaning the edges of the ulcer and apply the Omental patch

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with diffuse abdominal pain and abdominal wall rigidity. Exploratory laparotomy was done and the following was found. What would you do in the management of this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Simple primary repair

 

The scenario described suggests that the patient has a perforation of the small bowel, as indicated by the image showing a hole in the intestine. Abdominal wall rigidity is indicative of peritonitis, which results from the leakage of intestinal contents into the peritoneal cavity due to a perforation. The provided images and description align with a small bowel perforation, likely in the jejunum or ileum.

 

In cases of small bowel perforations, particularly when the perforation is small, the standard management is a simple primary repair. This involves suturing the perforation directly, which is often sufficient to manage the defect without the need for more extensive surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resection of the diseased segment and end-to-end anastomosis:
This is typically reserved for cases where the perforation is large, there are multiple perforations, or when the perforation is associated with a pathological condition like a stricture like in tubercular perforation. In the case described, a simple primary repair is usually sufficient.

 

Option B. Cleaning the edges of the ulcer and apply the Omental patch: This procedure, known as an omental patch or Graham's patch, is more commonly used for duodenal ulcers, not for small bowel perforations.

 

Option D. Purse string suture: This technique is not commonly used for repairing small bowel perforations. It is more suitable for specific types of perforations or fistulas but not typically indicated in the described scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For small bowel perforations, particularly in the jejunum or ileum, the primary approach is often a simple primary repair. This involves directly suturing the perforation and is usually effective for managing small perforations.

choices.text: Give shock with 2 J/kg and check pulse
Give shock with 2 J/kg and continue CPR for 2 mins
Continue CPR till pulse is back

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is undergoing CPR. He is pulseless and shows the below ECG. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give shock with 2 J/kg and continue CPR for 2 mins

 

The ECG shown in the image is indicative of ventricular tachycardia . Pulseless VT is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate defibrillation. The appropriate treatment for VT during CPR is to deliver an unsynchronized shock (defibrillation) at an initial dose of 2 J/kg. After delivering the shock, it is crucial to immediately resume CPR for 2 minutes before reassessing the rhythm and pulse, as this maximizes the chances of successful resuscitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give shock with 2 J/kg and check pulse: This option is incorrect because checking the pulse immediately after delivering the shock wastes valuable time. The correct protocol is to immediately resume CPR after the shock, without pausing to check the pulse, as this enhances the likelihood of restoring circulation.

 

Option C. Synchronized cardioversion: Synchronized cardioversion is used for treating certain types of arrhythmias, such as supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) or atrial fibrillation (AF), but it is not appropriate for pulseless ventricular tachycardia. In pulseless VT , unsynchronized defibrillation is required.

 

Option D. Continue CPR till pulse is back: This option is partially correct but incomplete. While continuing CPR is essential, the most crucial intervention in the case of pulseless VT is defibrillation. Without delivering a shock, the chances of survival are significantly diminished.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In a pediatric cardiac arrest with pulseless ventricular tachycardia on the ECG, the correct immediate action is to defibrillate with 2 J/kg and continue CPR for 2 minutes before reassessing.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with black deposit in the vertebrae visible on X-Ray LS spine and also over knee joint and sclera which shows ochronosis. Which enzyme deficiency has caused this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Homogentisic acid oxidase

 

The clinical presentation describes Alkaptonuria, which is caused by deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase (also known as homogentisate dioxygenase). This is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by:

 

  • Accumulation of homogentisic acid which gets oxidized to form black colored alkapton bodies
  • These alkapton bodies deposit in various tissues causing ochronosis: 
    • Sclera (causing black discoloration)
    • Cartilage of joints (causing arthritis)
    • Vertebral column (visible on X-ray)
    • Skin showing bluish-black color
  • The condition typically presents in adults around 30-40 years
  • Homogentisic acid gets excreted in urine, causing urine to turn black on standing (characteristic feature)
  • FeCl3 test of urine is positive
  • Part of Garrod's tetrad (along with albinism, cystinuria, and pentosuria)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency: Causes phenylketonuria (PKU) characterized by mental retardation, musty odor, and hypopigmentation. Does not cause ochronosis.

 

Option C. Tyrosine transaminase deficiency: Causes tyrosinemia type II (Richner-Hanhart syndrome) characterized by corneal ulcers and hyperkeratotic plaques. No ochronosis.

 

Option D. PHPP (para-hydroxy phenyl pyruvate) dioxygenase deficiency: Causes tyrosinemia type III characterized by mental retardation and ataxia but no ochronosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkaptonuria is caused by homogentisic acid oxidase deficiency and presents with ochronosis (black deposits in connective tissues) and darkening of urine on standing.

choices.text: Total body water is more than adults

questions.text: Dehydration usually affects an infant’s more than adults. Which of the following is a true statement in this scenario related to infants / Newborn? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ECF more than ICF

 

Explanation:

 

In newborns/infants, the ECF is greater than ICF, which makes them more susceptible to dehydration. 

 

  • ECF is greater than ICF in newborns
  • At 3-4 months of age, ICF equals ECF (50:50)
  • After 3-4 months, ICF gradually increases while ECF decreases
  • This higher ECF makes infants more vulnerable to fluid losses and dehydration

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ICF more than ECF: Incorrect. Because in newborns, ECF is higher than ICF. ICF becomes greater than ECF only after 3-4 months of age.

 

Option C. Total body water is more than adults: Incorrect. Because while newborns have a higher percentage of total body water (75%) compared to adults (60%), the absolute amount of water is less in newborns due to their smaller body size.

 

Option D. ECF equals ICF: Incorrect. Because ECF equals ICF only at around 3-4 months of age, not in newborns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In newborns, extracellular fluid (ECF) volume is greater than intracellular fluid (ICF) volume, which makes them more susceptible to dehydration compared to adults.

questions.text: The floods had an impact on Kerala's Pathanamthitta district, leading the government to provide doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis. What other chemical is set to be distributed in conjunction with this? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Zinc phosphide

 

Explanation - 

 

The government distributed doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis following floods in Kerala to prevent the spread of diseases such as leptospirosis, acute diarrheal diseases, and dengue.

  • Leptospirosis, which is caused by contaminated water with rodent urine, can be prevented by chemoprophylaxis with Doxycycline, using rubber shoes and gloves, anti-rodent measures, and establishing a proper drainage system.
  • Zinc phosphide is used for chemical control of rodents due to its good safety record, low cost and high effectiveness
  • Chlorine tablets and bleaching powder are used to disinfect household water supply. Insecticides and larvicides like abate are used for indoor residual sprays for drinking water.
  • General hygiene and sanitary measures must also be followed to control the spread of diseases during floods.

choices.text: Metastatic calcification with normal serum Ca²⁺ levels
Metastatic calcification with increased serum Ca²⁺ levels
Dystrophic calcification with normal serum Ca²⁺ levels
Dystrophic calcification with increased serum Ca²⁺ levels

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with cervical lymphadenopathy and fever. The biopsy has revealed granulomatous necrotizing inflammation. Which of the following is the likely finding with this presentation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dystrophic calcification with normal serum Ca²⁺ levels

 

The patient described has a granulomatous necrotizing inflammation, which is highly suggestive of tuberculosis, particularly in regions where tuberculosis is prevalent. Tuberculosis often leads to the formation of caseating granulomas, which can undergo dystrophic calcification.

 

Dystrophic calcification occurs in areas of tissue damage or necrosis, such as caseating granulomas in tuberculosis. This type of calcification is characterized by the deposition of calcium salts in dead or degenerating tissues, and importantly, it occurs despite normal serum calcium levels.

 

In contrast, metastatic calcification occurs in normal tissues and is associated with hypercalcemia, which is not the case here.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metastatic calcification with normal serum Ca²⁺ levels: Metastatic calcification is not associated with normal calcium levels. It is typically associated with elevated serum calcium levels.

 

Option B. Metastatic calcification with increased serum Ca²⁺ levels: While metastatic calcification does occur with increased serum calcium levels, it is not related to granulomatous necrotizing inflammation like that seen in tuberculosis. This is seen in Sarcoidosis, parathyroid adenoma, chronic kidney disease, William syndrome.

 

Option D. Dystrophic calcification with increased serum Ca²⁺ levels: Dystrophic calcification occurs in the context of normal serum calcium levels, not increased levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dystrophic calcification is a common finding in tissues undergoing necrosis, such as in caseating granulomas in tuberculosis, and it occurs with normal serum calcium levels.

questions.text: One mother had brought her child for evaluation of diphtheria in which the child had low-grade fever, pseudomembranes over the tonsils, and one sibling is fully immunized. What will be the prophylaxis given to her sibling? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Erythromycin

 

The Ans. is Erythromycin. In cases where a household member is diagnosed with diphtheria, all close contacts, including fully immunized siblings, should be given prophylactic treatment regardless of their immunization status.

 

The recommended prophylaxis for contacts is oral Erythromycin for seven days or a single dose of benzathine penicillin. This approach aims to prevent the spread of Corynebacterium diphtheriae and the development of active diphtheria lesions in contacts, even if they are asymptomatic and immunized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diphtheria booster single dose: A booster dose of the diphtheria toxoid is recommended for previously immunized individuals who are diagnosed with diphtheria but are asymptomatic. This does not apply to the contact sibling who is already fully immunized and not infected.

 

Option C. Diphtheria toxoid full course: A full course of the diphtheria toxoid is not necessary for a fully immunized sibling who is a contact. This option would be considered for individuals who are not up-to-date with their diphtheria vaccinations.

 

Option D. Nothing is required: This option is incorrect because all household contacts of a diphtheria case should receive prophylactic treatment to prevent possible infection and transmission, even if they are asymptomatic and fully immunized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For fully immunized close contacts of a diphtheria case, the recommended prophylaxis is a seven-day course of oral Erythromycin or a single dose of benzathine penicillin.

questions.text: A patient is a known case of hypertension and is on multiple antihypertensive drugs. His ECG is shown below. Which drug is responsible for the following ECG? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Spironolactone

 

The ECG shows tall, tented T waves, absent P waves (atrial standstill), and a severely widened QRS complex. These are classic signs of severe hyperkalemia.

 

Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that can cause hyperkalemia. It is known for increasing potassium levels in the blood by inhibiting the effects of aldosterone, leading to decreased excretion of potassium in the urine.

 

Therefore, the drug most likely responsible for the ECG findings is Spironolactone due to its potent potassium-sparing effects leading to severe hyperkalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hydrochlorothiazide: Causes hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Can cause mild hyperkalemia but not to the extent seen in the ECG.

 

Option D. Prazosin: Does not affect potassium levels significantly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spironolactone, a potassium-sparing diuretic, can cause severe hyperkalemia, which is characterized by tall, tented T waves, absent P waves, and widened QRS complexes on an ECG.

questions.text: A child presents with Patent Ductus Arteriosus, Cataract, and Salt & Pepper Retinopathy. This is suggestive of which intrauterine infection? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rubella

 

Explanation: 

 

Congenital Rubella Syndrome is characterized by the classic triad:

 

  • C: Cataract (nuclear pearly or lamellar)
  • H: Heart disease (Patent Ductus Arteriosus)
  • D: Deafness

 

Additional specific findings include:

 

  • Salt and pepper retinopathy
  • Micro-ophthalmia
  • Potential glaucoma
  • Characteristic nuclear pearly cataract

 

The syndrome results from maternal rubella infection during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester.
 

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Toxoplasma: Incorrect. While it can cause congenital infections, it does not match the specific triad described.

 

  • Toxoplasma triad: Intracranial calcification, chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus

 

Option B. Varicella: Incorrect. Does not cause the described constellation of symptoms.

 

Option D. Cytomegalovirus: Incorrect. While it can cause congenital infections, the specific triad is not consistent with CMV.

 

Educational Objective: 


Classic CHD (Cataract, Heart disease, Deafness) triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome, with salt and pepper retinopathy as a characteristic finding.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not associated with Pancoast tumor? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Exophthalmos

 

Explanation:

 
Pancoast tumor (superior sulcus tumor) is a lung tumor at the apex that affects the sympathetic pathway leading to Horner's syndrome. The classic triad of Horner's syndrome includes ptosis (due to paralysis of Müller's muscle), miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae), and anhidrosis (due to involvement of sweat glands). Patients exhibit apparent enophthalmos (not exophthalmos) due to the narrowing of the palpebral aperture from ptosis, making the eye appear sunken.

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Ptosis: Is a classic finding in Pancoast tumor due to involvement of sympathetic supply to Müller's muscle, causing 2mm of ptosis.

 

Option C. Anhidrosis: Is a characteristic finding due to involvement of sympathetic supply to sweat glands on the affected side.

 

Option D. Miosis: Is present due to unopposed parasympathetic action on the pupil following sympathetic denervation of the dilator pupillae.

 

Educational Objective:


Pancoast tumor can invade the sympathetic chain, causing Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis). However, it does NOT cause exophthalmos, which is more commonly seen in conditions like thyroid eye disease or orbital tumors

choices.text: Do USG, don’t see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman
Do USG, see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman
Do USG, see the fetus gender and tell the woman

questions.text: G5P4 lady with 4 female children reports for the first time at 18 weeks POG. As per the PCPNDT Act and Beti Bachao Andolan, what will you do? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Do USG, don’t see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman

 

In India, the Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PCPNDT) Act, 1994, strictly prohibits the determination of fetal sex to prevent female feticide. The act is a legal measure to curb the misuse of diagnostic techniques for sex determination, which could lead to gender-selective abortions. This law aligns with the Beti Bachao Beti Padhao initiative, which aims to save and educate the girl child.

 

In the given scenario, the woman is at 18 weeks of gestation. A USG (ultrasound) scan is recommended to assess fetal health and pregnancy progress but not to determine the fetus's gender. Neither the radiologist nor the obstetrician/gynecologist should attempt to determine or disclose the fetus's gender unless there is a valid legal or medical reason, which is rare and strictly controlled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Don’t do the USG scan: This option is incorrect because USG is an important tool for monitoring fetal development and maternal health. Refusing to perform a USG scan without medical justification would be inappropriate and neglectful of standard prenatal care.

 

Option C. Do USG, see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman:  This option is incorrect because, under the PCPNDT Act, healthcare professionals are prohibited from determining the gender of the fetus during a USG scan unless medically indicated. Viewing the fetus's gender without a valid reason is a violation of the law.

 

Option D.  Do USG, see the fetus gender and tell the woman: This option is incorrect and illegal as per the PCPNDT Act. Disclosing the gender of the fetus to the expectant mother or any other person is punishable by law, as it could lead to gender-based discrimination and sex-selective abortions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal sex determination and disclosure are illegal under the PCPNDT Act unless medically indicated. During routine prenatal care, USG should be performed without determining or revealing the fetus's gender.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Saline infusion sonography

questions.text: A female patient has a history of three miscarriages. Identify the investigation that was done from the image shown below? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hysterosalpingography

 

  • This is an image of a Hysterosalpingogram (HSG)
  • An HSG is used to
    • Delineate uterine anomalies.
    • Endometrial cavity lesions like polyps, adhesions
    • Tubal patency in infertility

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysteroscopy: Hysteroscopy appears like this image. Using fluid media to distend the uterine cavity, a hysteroscope can visualize the inside of the uterine cavity.

 

 

Option B. Saline infusion sonography: Saline infusion sonography: This is an ultrasound-based investigation, wherein saline is injected in the uterine cavity and this helps detect intra-uterine space occupying lesions and appears like this:

 

 

Option D. Transvaginal ultrasound: This appears like this:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is an X-ray procedure used to delineate uterine anomalies, identify endometrial cavity lesions, and assess tubal patency in cases of infertility.

 

Ref: Page no 588, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition
